Mexico, D.F.: Instituto Nacional de Antropología y Historia. *{{aut|Beekman, Christopher S}} (1994) "[https://web.archive.org/web/20090306000741/http://carbon.cudenver.edu/~cbeekman/articles/saa94pap.pdf A Classic Period Political Boundary in the Sierra La Primavera Region, Jalisco, Mexico]", presented at the 59th Annual Meeting of the Society for American Archaeology, Anaheim. *{{aut|Beekman, Christopher S}} (1996) "[https://web.archive.org/web/20090306000631/http://carbon.cudenver.edu/~cbeekman/articles/am96pap.pdf Political Boundaries and Political Structure: the Limits of the Teuchitlan Tradition]" in ''Ancient Mesoamerica'', Vol 7, No 1, pp. 135–147. *{{aut|Smith, Michael E.}} (2007) "Form and Meaning in the Earliest Cities: A New Approach to Ancient Urban Planning" in ''Journal of Planning History'', Vol. 6, No. 1, pp. 3–47. *{{aut|Weigand, Phil}} (2001) "West Mexico Classic" in ''Encyclopedia of Prehistory'', Vol 5, [[Peter N. Peregrine]] (ed), {{ISBN|978-0-306-46259-7}}. *{{aut|Weigand, Phil C. and Christopher S. Beekman}} (1999) "La Civilización Teuchitlan" in ''La Jornada, Suplemento Cultural'', vol 210, no 1-4. Accessed May 2008. *{{aut|Weigand, Phil and Efraín Cárdenas}}, "[https://web.archive.org/web/20081006223317/http://carbon.cudenver.edu/~cbeekman/research/guachimonton.html Proyecto Arqueológico Teuchitlán]", accessed May 2008. *{{aut|Williams, Eduardo}}, "[http://www.famsi.org/research/williams/index.html Prehispanic West México: A Mesoamerican Culture Area]", Foundation for the Advancement of Mesoamerican Studies, Inc., accessed May 2008. ==External links== * [http://ixtlandelrio.nayarit.gob.mx/ Ixtlán del Rio Municipal Government Portal {{es icon}}] * [http://www.e-local.gob.mx/work/templates/enciclo/nayarit/mpios/18006a.htm Enciclopedia de los Municipios de México, Ixtlán del Río, Nayarit {{es icon}}] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101016225101/http://www.teuchitlan.mx/ Teuchitlán, Jalisco. Official Web Site] {{es icon}} * [http://www.CloniX.tk More information on Teuchitlán and Guachimontones] {{es icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110722222942/http://galerias.ahualulco.com.mx/main.php?g2_itemId=652 Galería de Fotos de Guachimontones] {{es icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ixtlan del Rio (archaeological site)}} [[Category:Mesoamerican sites]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in Nayarit]] [[Category:Mesoamerican art]] [[Category:Petroglyphs in Mexico]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Nayarit]]

{{Distinguish|Rylands Building}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox building | name = John Rylands Library | native_name = | native_name_lang = | former_names = | alternate_names = Rylands Library | status = Grade I listed | image = Rylands Library Deansgate.jpg | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | altitude = | building_type = Library | architectural_style = [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] [[Neo-Gothic]] | structural_system = | cost = £200,000<ref>{{Citation |title=John Rylands Library |url=http://www.engineering-timelines.com/scripts/engineeringItem.asp?id=1093 |work=Engineering Timelines |accessdate=25 February 2012}}</ref><ref>According to Clare Hartwell the cost was £230,000:-{{citation |page=96 |first= Clare |last=Hartwell |series=Pevsner Architectural Guides |title=Manchester |publisher=Penguin Books |year=2001 |location=London|isbn=978-0-14-071131-8}}</ref> | location = [[Deansgate]], [[Manchester]], England |mapframe=no | coordinates = {{coord|53.480321|-2.2487|display=inline,title}} | start_date = 1890 | completion_date = 1899<ref name="jrl_plan">{{cite web | url=http://www.manchester2002-uk.com/maps/john-rylands-map.html | title=Plan of John Rylands Library, Manchester | accessdate=29 April 2007 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E1zc6ebt?url=http://www.manchester2002-uk.com/maps/john-rylands-map.html | archivedate=29 January 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> | opened_date = 1 January 1900 | inauguration_date = 6 October 1899 | renovation_date = 1920, 1962, 2003–07 | main_contractor = R. and W. Morrison, Liverpool | architect = [[Basil Champneys]]<ref name="jrl_plan"/> | url = [http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/deansgate/ Rylands Library website] | embedded = | references = }} The '''John Rylands Library''' is a [[Victorian era|late-Victorian]] [[Gothic Revival architecture|neo-Gothic]] building on [[Deansgate]] in [[Manchester]], England. The library, which opened to the public in 1900, was founded by [[Enriqueta Augustina Rylands]] in memory of her husband, [[John Rylands]].<ref name="special_collection_information">{{cite web | url=http://rylibweb.man.ac.uk/spcoll/visitor/ | title=JRUL Special Collections: Visitor Information | accessdate=29 April 2007 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120718094851/http://rylibweb.man.ac.uk/spcoll/visitor/ | archivedate=18 July 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The John Rylands Library and the library of the University of Manchester merged in July 1972 into the [[University of Manchester Library|John Rylands University Library of Manchester]]; today it is part of The [[University of Manchester Library]].
Special collections built up by both libraries were progressively concentrated in the Deansgate building. The special collections, believed to be among the largest in the United Kingdom,<ref>{{Cite news |title=What are Special Collections? |url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/academicsupport/usingspecialcollections/whatare-specialcollections/ |work=University of Manchester |accessdate=6 January 2012}}</ref> include [[medieval]] [[illuminated manuscript]]s and examples of early European printing, including a [[Gutenberg Bible]], the second largest collection of printing by [[William Caxton]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/searchresources/guidetospecialcollections/atoz/incunabulacollection/ |title=Incunabula Collection | accessdate=25 February 2012|publisher=The University of Manchester}}</ref> and the most extensive collection of the editions of the [[Aldus Manutius|Aldine Press]] of Venice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/searchresources/guidetospecialcollections/atoz/aldinecollection/ |title=Aldine Press| accessdate=25 February 2012|publisher=The University of Manchester}}</ref> The [[Rylands Library Papyrus P52]] has a claim to be the earliest extant [[New Testament]] text. The library holds personal papers and letters of notable figures, among them [[Elizabeth Gaskell]] and [[John Dalton]].
The architectural style is primarily neo-Gothic with elements of [[Arts and Crafts Movement]] in the ornate and imposing gatehouse facing Deansgate which dominates the surrounding streetscape. The library, granted [[Grade I listed buildings in Greater Manchester#Manchester|Grade I listed status]] in 1994, is maintained by the [[University of Manchester]] and open for library readers and visitors.
==History== Enriqueta Rylands purchased a site on Deansgate for her memorial library in 1889 and commissioned a design from architect [[Basil Champneys]].<ref name="special_collection_information" /><ref>Farnie, D. A. (1989) "Enriqueta Augustina Rylands" in: ''[[Bulletin of the John Rylands University Library of Manchester]]'', LXXI, 2 (summer 1989); pp. 3–38</ref> Rylands commissioned the Manchester academic [[Alice Margaret Cooke|Alice Cooke]] to index the vast library of the [[George Spencer, 2nd Earl Spencer|2nd Earl Spencer]] which she had purchased and another collection of autographs.<ref name=perrone>Fernanda Helen Perrone, ‘Cooke, Alice Margaret (1867–1940)’, [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]], Oxford University Press, 2004 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/62414, accessed 26 Dec 2015]</ref> Mrs Rylands intended the library to be principally [[theology|theological]], and the building, which is a fine example of Victorian Gothic, has the appearance of a [[church (building)|church]], although the concept was of an Oxford college library on a larger scale.<ref name="Farnie 1989">Farnie (1989)</ref> Champneys presented plans to Mrs Rylands within a week of gaining the commission. Thereafter frequent disagreements arose and Mrs Rylands selected decorative elements, window glass and statues against his wishes.<ref>{{Citation |title=Basil Champneys (1842–1935) |url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/deansgate/ourhistory/thepeople/basilchampneys/ |publisher=University of Manchester (The) |accessdate=25 February 2012}}</ref>
Champneys was given the honour of speaking about the library at a general meeting of the [[Royal Institute of British Architects]] and was awarded a [[Royal Gold Medal]] in 1912.<ref name="Bowler 2000 187"/> The library was granted [[listed building]] status on 25 January 1952, which was upgraded to Grade I on 6 June 1994.<ref name = "NHLE">{{National Heritage List for England |num= 1217800|desc= John Rylands Library and Attached Railings, Gates and Lamp Standards|access-date= 27 September 2012}}</ref>
The core of the library's collection was formed around 40,000 books, including many rarities, assembled by [[George Spencer, 2nd Earl Spencer]], which Mrs Rylands purchased from Lord Spencer in 1892.<ref name="special_collection">{{cite web | url=http://rylibweb.man.ac.uk/data2/spcoll/ | title = JRUL: Special Collections Guide | accessdate=29 April 2007}}</ref> She had begun acquiring books in 1889 and continued to do so throughout her lifetime.<ref name="Farnie 1989">Farnie (1989)</ref> After its inauguration on 6 October 1899 (the wedding anniversary of John Rylands and Enriqueta Tennant)<ref name="Farnie 1989">Farnie (1989)</ref> the library opened to readers and visitors on 1 January 1900.<ref name="special_collection_information" />
The John Rylands Library and the library of the [[Victoria University of Manchester|University of Manchester]] merged in July 1972 and was named the John Rylands University Library of Manchester. Special collections built up by both libraries were progressively concentrated in the Deansgate building.
The building has been extended four times, the first time to designs by Champneys in 1920 after the project was delayed by [[World War I]]. The [[Isaac Wolfson|Lady Wolfson Building]] opened in 1962 on the west side and a third extension, south of the first was built in 1969. In January 2003, an appeal to renovate the building was launched.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Appeal to restore historic library |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2678977.stm |work=BBC News |date=21 January 2003 |accessdate=17 February 2013}}</ref> Funds were generated from grants from the University of Manchester and [[Heritage Lottery Fund]] and donations from members of the public and companies in Manchester.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Library closes for refit |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/3106460.stm |work=BBC News |date=13 September 2003 |accessdate=17 February 2013}}</ref> The project, Unlocking the Rylands, demolished the third extension, refurbished parts of the old building and erected a pitched roof over its reinforced concrete roof. Champneys designed a pitched roof but Mrs Rylands was advised that an internal stone vault would reduce the fire risk and it was not built.<ref name="special_collection" /> The £17 million project was completed by summer 2007 and the library reopened on 20 September 2007.<ref>{{Cite news |title=City's historic library reopens |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/7004206.stm |work=BBC News |date=20 September 2007 |accessdate=17 February 2013}}</ref> {{clear}}
==Location== [[File:John Rylands Library 1.jpg|thumb|right|Facade of the John Rylands Library]] [[File:The John Rylands Library.jpg|thumb|right|Reading Room of the Rylands Library]] By the nineteenth century Manchester was a prosperous industrial town and the demands of [[Cotton mill|cotton manufacturing]] stimulated the growth of engineering and chemical industries. The town became 'abominably filthy' and was 'often covered, especially during the winter, with dense fogs ... there is at all times a copious descent of soots and other impurities'.<ref>{{Harvnb|Bowler|Brimblecombe|2000|p=176}}</ref> This, and the overcrowded site, created many design problems for the architect.<ref name="Bowler 2000 177">{{Harvnb|Bowler|Brimblecombe|2000|p=177}}</ref> During the century most textile manufacture moved to newer mills in the surrounding towns while Manchester remained the centre of trading in cotton goods both for the home and foreign markets but pollution from burning coal and gas remained a considerable nuisance.
The site chosen by Mrs Rylands was in a central and fashionable part of the city, but was awkward in shape and orientation and surrounded by tall warehouses, derelict cottages and narrow streets.<ref name="Bowler 2000 177"/> The position was criticised for its lack of surrounding space and the fact that the valuable manuscript collections were to be housed in "that dirty, uncomfortable city ... [with] not enough light to read by, and the books they already have are wretchedly kept" (written in 1901 about the [[Crawford MSS]].)<ref name="Bowler 2000 177"/> Mrs Rylands negotiated Deeds of Agreement with her neighbours to fix the heights of future adjacent buildings. The permissible height of the building was fixed at just over 34 feet, but it was suggested that it could be taller at the centre if there was an open area around the edges, at the height of buildings that had been demolished to make way for the construction.<ref name="Bowler 2000 177"/> Champneys incorporated this suggestion into his design, setting the two towers of the facade twelve feet back from the boundary and keeping the entrance block low, to allow light into the library.<ref name="Bowler 2000 177"/> He designed the building in a series of tiered steps with an almost flat roof to give a 'liberal concession' to the neighbours' 'right to light'.<ref name="Bowler 2000 178">{{Harvnb|Bowler|Brimblecombe|2000|p=178}}</ref>
==Architecture==
===Exterior=== The library was built on a rectangular plan and subsequent extensions are to the rear. It was designed to resemble a church in a decorated neo-Gothic style with Arts and Crafts details.<ref name = "NHLE"/> It is constructed of Cumbrian [[sandstone]], the interior a delicately shaded 'Shawk' stone (from [[Dalston, Cumbria|Dalston]], varying in colour between sand and a range of pinks) and the exterior, dark red Barbary stone from [[Penrith, Cumbria|Penrith]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://enriqueta.man.ac.uk:8180/luna/servlet/detail/Manchester~91~1~95745~105447:Historic-Reading-Room|title=Historic Reading Room|work=John Rylands University Library Image Collections|publisher=John Rylands University Library|accessdate=3 December 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.genuki.org.uk/big/eng/CUL/Dalston/Gaz1868.html|title=Dalston, Cumberland|work=The National Gazetteer of Great Britain and Ireland, 1868|publisher=GENUKI|accessdate=3 December 2010}}</ref> built around an internal steel framed structure and brick arched flooring.<ref>{{Harvnb|Bowler|Brimblecombe|2000|p=179}}</ref> The red 'Barbary plain' sandstone, which Champneys believed 'had every chance of proving durable' for the exterior, was an unusual choice in late Victorian Manchester. It proved relatively successful, as an inspection by Champneys in 1900 revealed little softening by the 'effects of an atmosphere somewhat charged with chemicals' although, by 1909 some repairs were needed.<ref>{{Harvnb|Bowler|Brimblecombe|2000|p=181}}</ref>
The library has a [[crypt]] above which the building has two unequal storeys giving the impression of three. The ornate Deansgate facade has an [[embattled]] [[parapet]] with open-work arcading under which is a central three-[[Bay (architecture)|bay]] entrance resembling a monastery gatehouse. Its two-centred arched portal has doorways separated by a [[Trumeau (architecture)|trumeau]] and tall windows on either side. Above the doors are a pair of small [[Cant (architecture)|canted]] [[oriel window]]s. Surfaces are decorated with lacy blind tracery and finely-detailed carving.<ref name = "NHLE"/> The carving includes the "J. R." monogram, the arms of Rylands, the arms of Rylands' native town, St Helens, and those of five English, two Scottish and two Irish universities and those of [[Owens College]].<ref>{{Cite book|last=Guppy|first=Henry|title=The John Rylands Library, Manchester: 1899–1924: a record of its history |publisher=University Press|location=Manchester|year=1924|page=121}}</ref> On either side of the entrance portal are square two-storey two-bay wings with plain walls with a [[string course]] containing [[Grotesque#In architecture|grotesques]] and large octagonal [[Cupola|lanterns]]. Behind the entrance portal flanked by square towers is the three-light east window of the reading hall. It has reticulated tracery and shafts in a similar style to the parapet. In front of the library are Art Nouveau [[bronze]] railings with central double gates and lamp standards.<ref name = "NHLE"/>
===Interior=== The main reading room on the first floor, 30 feet above the ground and 12 feet from all four boundaries, was noted for the pleasant contrast between the 'sullen roar' of Manchester and the 'internal cloister quietude of Rylands'.<ref name="Bowler 2000 178"/> It was lit by oriel windows in the reading alcoves supplemented by high [[clerestory]] windows along both sides.<ref name="Bowler 2000 178"/> Embellishments in the reading room include two large stained glass windows with portraits of religious and secular figures, designed by [[Charles Eamer Kempe|C. E. Kempe]]; a series of statues in the reading room by [[Robert Bridgeman and Sons|Bridgeman's]] of Lichfield;<ref>"A series of portrait statues, designed by Mr. Robert Bridgeman, of Lichfield"--Guppy, H. (1924) ''The John Rylands Library, Manchester: 1899-1924''. Manchester: University Press; p. 122</ref> and bronzework in the art nouveau style by Singer of Frome. The portraits in sculpture (20) and stained glass (40) represent a selection of personages from the intellectual and artistic history of mankind. The western window contains "Theology" from Moses to Schleiermacher; the eastern "Literature and Art" (including philosophy).<ref>{{cite book|last=Guppy|first=Henry|title=The John Rylands Library, Manchester: 1899–1924: a record of its history |publisher=University Press|location=Manchester|year=1924|pages=122–23}}</ref> The portrait statues of John and Enriqueta Rylands in [[white marble]], in the reading room, were sculpted by [[John Cassidy (artist)|John Cassidy]] who also executed the allegorical group of 'Theology, Science and Art' in the vestibule.<ref name="special_collection_information"/><ref>John Rylands and the allegorical group were completed for the inauguration, 6 October 1899; Enriqueta's statue was completed in December 1907 and portrays her at the age of her marriage in 1875.</ref>
Aside from the main library and reading room with gallery above, the design incorporated Bible and map rooms on the first floor, and conference (lecture) and committee rooms on the ground floor, part of which was intended to be a lending library but never operated as such. A caretaker's house was incorporated in the building until it was demolished for the extension of 1969.<ref name="jrl_plan"/>
===Technology=== Electric lighting was chosen as the cleanest and safest alternative to gas but, as the use of electricity was in its early stages, the supply (110 volts DC) was generated on-site. This took some years to achieve due to the inexperience of contractors,<ref name="Bowler 2000 187">{{Harvnb|Bowler|Brimblecombe|2000|p=187}}</ref> but the library became one of the first public buildings in Manchester to be lit by electricity<ref name="special_collection_information" /><ref>An electrical power supply was available in Manchester city centre from 1893, from the Dickinson Street generating station.--McKechnie, H. M., ed. (1915) ''Manchester in Nineteen Hundred and Fifteen''. Manchester: University Press; p. 27</ref> and continued to generate its own supply until 1950.<ref name="Bowler 2000 185"/>
Champneys suggested that, in order to protect the books and manuscripts, 'it will be very desirable to keep the air in the interior of the building as clear and free from smoke and chemical matter (both of which are held in the air of Manchester) as may be possible'.<ref name="Bowler 2000 185">{{Harvnb|Bowler|Brimblecombe|2000|p=185}}</ref> The ground floor was built with numerous air inlets and, although his client felt it would prove impossible to exclude foul air, Champneys installed jute or hessian screens to trap the soot, with water sprays to catch the sulphur and other chemicals,<ref name="Bowler 2000 185"/> which was a very advanced system for the period.<ref name="special_collection_information" /> Internal screen doors were employed in the entrance hall to prevent the air being 'fouled by the opening of the outer doors' with internal swing doors between the circulation areas and the main library to 'preserve the valuable books from injury'.<ref name="Bowler 2000 185"/> By 1900 the ventilation system had evolved to include electric fans to draw in air at pavement level through [[Petroleum coke|coke]] screens sprayed with water.<ref name="Bowler 2000 185"/>
==Collections== [[File:Manchester John Rylands Library James Joyce 16-10-2009 13-55-16.JPG|thumb|First edition of ''Ulysses'' by [[James Joyce]]]] [[File:Rylands papyrus.jpg|thumb|The [[Papyrus 52]] (fragment of the Gospel of John) at the John Rylands Library]] On opening in 1900, the library had 70,000 books and fewer than 100 manuscripts<ref>{{Cite news |title=Our history - The Library opens |url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/deansgate/ourhistory/ |work=University of Manchester |accessdate=12 September 2012}}</ref> and by 2012, more than 250,000 printed volumes and over one million manuscripts and archival items.<ref>{{Cite news |title=John Rylands Library - Our history |url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/deansgate/ourhistory/ |work=University of Manchester |accessdate=12 September 2012}}</ref> The main foundation of the library's collections acquired in 1892 was the ''Althorp Library'' of [[John Spencer, 5th Earl Spencer|Lord Spencer]] regarded as one of the finest library collections in private ownership with 43,000 items - 3,000 of which originate from before 1501 (i.e. incunabula).<ref>{{Cite news |title=Spencer collection |url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/searchresources/guidetospecialcollections/atoz/spencercollection/ |work=University of Manchester |accessdate=12 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=How did these books come to Manchester? |url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/firstimpressions/The-Collection/How-did-these-books-come-to-Manchester/ |work=University of Manchester |accessdate=12 September 2012}}</ref> Mrs Rylands paid £210,000 for Spencer's collection which included the [[Aldine Press#Collections|Aldine Collection]]<ref>{{Cite news |title=Aldine Collection |url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/searchresources/guidetospecialcollections/atoz/aldinecollection/ |work=University of Manchester |accessdate=12 September 2012}}</ref> and an [[Incunable|incunabula]] collection of 3,000 items.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Incunabula collection |url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/searchresources/guidetospecialcollections/atoz/incunabulacollection/ |work=University of Manchester |accessdate=12 September 2012}}</ref>
Owens College Library received [[Richard Copley Christie]]'s library of over 8,000 volumes including many rare books from the [[Renaissance]] period in 1901.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Christie collection |url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/searchresources/guidetospecialcollections/atoz/christiecollection/ |publisher=University of Manchester |accessdate=12 September 2012}}</ref> It was part of the Victoria University of Manchester library from 1904 and was transferred to the John Rylands Library building after the merger in 1972. In 1901, Mrs Rylands paid £155,000 for more than 6,000 manuscripts owned by [[James Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford]] of [[Haigh Hall]]. The [[James Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford#The Bibliotheca Lindesiana|''Bibliotheca Lindesiana'']] was one of the most impressive private collections in Britain at the time, both for its size and rarity of some of its contents.<ref>Guppy, Henry (1946) "The ''Bibliotheca Lindesiana''", in: ''Bulletin of the John Rylands Library''; vol. 30, pp. 185–94</ref><ref>Barker, Nicolas (1978) ''Bibliotheca Lindesiana: the lives and collections of Alexander William, 25th Earl of Crawford and 8th Earl of Balcarres and James Ludovic, 26th Earl of Crawford and 9th Earl of Balcarres''. London: Quaritch for the Roxburghe Club; pp. 350–54, 361-62</ref> [[Walter Llewellyn Bullock]] bequeathed 5,000 items (notably early Italian imprints) during the 1930s.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Bullock collection |url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/searchresources/guidetospecialcollections/atoz/bullockcollection/ |work=University of Manchester |accessdate=12 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504171342/http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/searchresources/guidetospecialcollections/atoz/bullockcollection/ |archivedate=4 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The library's collections include exquisite medieval illuminated manuscripts, examples of early European printing including a fine paper copy of the [[Gutenberg Bible]] and books printed by [[William Caxton]], and personal papers of distinguished historical figures including Elizabeth Gaskell, John Dalton and [[John Wesley]].<ref name="special_collection" /> Nothing is known of the early history of this copy of the Gutenberg Bible before it was acquired by the 2nd Earl Spencer.<ref>There are 48 complete or nearly complete extant copies of the Gutenberg Bible of which a few are on vellum. [http://www.bl.uk/treasures/gutenberg/copieselse.html Gutenberg in the British Library at bl.uk]</ref><ref>The copy has some illuminated initial letters and the leaves are uncut (without trimming of the margins); MS. notes to guide the illuminator are near the top edges of the pages. The two folio volumes were rebound in blue morocco for Lord Spencer.</ref>
The library houses [[papyrus]] fragments known as the [[Rylands Papyri]] and documents from [[North Africa]]. The most notable are the ''St John Fragment'', believed to be the oldest extant [[New Testament]] text, [[Rylands Library Papyrus P52]], the earliest fragment of the text of the canonical Gospel of John;<ref name="papyrus">{{cite web|url=http://rylibweb.man.ac.uk/data1/dg/text/fragment.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070421182600/http://rylibweb.man.ac.uk/data1/dg/text/fragment.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 April 2007 |title=An Unpublished Fragment of the Fourth Gospel |publisher=JRUL |accessdate=29 April 2007 |df= }}</ref> the earliest fragment of the [[Septuagint]], [[Papyrus Rylands 458]]; and [[Papyrus Rylands 463]], a manuscript fragment of the apocryphal Gospel of Mary. [[Minuscule 702]], ε2010 ([[Biblical manuscript#Von Soden|von Soden]]),<ref name = Soden>[[Hermann von Soden]], ''Die Schriften des neuen Testaments, in ihrer ältesten erreichbaren Textgestalt / hergestellt auf Grund ihrer Textgeschichte'' (Berlin, 1902), vol. 1, p. 169</ref> is a [[Greek language|Greek]] [[List of New Testament minuscules|minuscule]] [[manuscript]] of the [[New Testament]], on parchment. Among the [[Oxyrhynchus Papyri|papyri from Oxyrhynchus]] are a homily about women (Inv R. 55247), part of the [[Book of Tobit]] (Apocrypha) (448), and [[Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 73]], relating to the transfer of a slave. The Arabic papyri were catalogued by [[David Samuel Margoliouth]]; his catalogue was published in 1933.<ref>Margoliouth, D. S. (1933) ''Catalogue of Arabic Papyri in the John Rylands Library, Manchester''. Manchester</ref>
In addition to the collections of Spencer, Crawford, Christie and [[Walter Bullock|Bullock]],<ref>{{cite web|title= Bullock Collection, The University of Manchester, The John Rylands University Library|url= http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/searchresources/guidetospecialcollections/atoz/bullockcollection/|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120504171342/http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/searchresources/guidetospecialcollections/atoz/bullockcollection/|archivedate= 4 May 2012|df= dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Bullock Collection, The John Rylands Library|url= http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/deansgate/ourhistory/thecollections/|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110720193342/http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/deansgate/ourhistory/thecollections/|archivedate= 20 July 2011|df= dmy-all}}</ref> holdings have been enriched by gifts, permanent loans or purchases of several libraries belonging to institutions and individuals. These include the French Revolution Broadsides donated by the 27th Earl of Crawford in 1924<ref>"The 'Bibliotheca Lindesiana'", in: ''The Bulletin of the John Rylands Library''; vol. 30, no. 1, 1946p. 11</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/searchresources/guidetospecialcollections/atoz/frenchrevolutioncollection/ |title=French Revolution Collection|publisher=University of Manchester (The)|accessdate=29 February 2012}}</ref> and the archives of the [[Methodist Church of Great Britain]] in 1977.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/searchresources/guidetospecialcollections/methodist/ |title=Methodist Collections |publisher=University of Manchester (The)|accessdate=29 February 2012}}</ref> Between 1946 and 1988 a number of sections of the Earl of Crawford's library were deposited here,<ref>Guppy, Henry (1946) "The 'Bibliotheca Lindesiana'", in: ''Bulletin of the John Rylands Library''; vol. 30, pp. 185–94</ref> however all but one of these were withdrawn in 1988.
Mrs Rylands died in 1908 having bequeathed her private collections and an endowment of £200,000 to enable the library to expand. The funds were used to acquire 180,000 books, 3,000 manuscripts and extend the building.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Our History - Enriqueta Rylands |url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/deansgate/ourhistory/ |work=University of Manchester |accessdate=12 September 2012}}</ref> The Librarian, [[Henry Guppy (librarian)|Henry Guppy]], invited individuals to deposit their archives for safe keeping in 1921 when there were no [[county record office]]s in Lancashire or Cheshire and the library became one of the first to collect historical family records.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Our History - Family archives deposited |url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/deansgate/ourhistory/ |work=University of Manchester |accessdate=12 September 2012}}</ref>
==Staff== Librarians at John Rylands before its merger include [[Edward Gordon Duff]] in 1899 and 1900 and Henry Guppy between 1899 and 1948 (joint Librarian with Duff until 1900). Duff was responsible for the original library catalogue, compiled between 1893 and 1899: ''Catalogue of the Printed Books and Manuscripts in the John Rylands Library, Manchester''; ed. E. G. Duff. Manchester: J. E. Cornish, 1899. 3 vols.<ref name="Farnie 1989"/> The cataloguing of the books was done by [[Alice Margaret Cooke]], a graduate of the Victoria University.<ref>[http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/firstimpressions/Pioneers-of-Print/Enriqueta-Rylands/ Enriqueta Rylands], First Impressions, University of Manchester, Retrieved 5 January 2016</ref> Dr Guppy began publication of the ''[[Bulletin of the John Rylands Library]]'' in 1903; it later became a journal publishing academic articles and from autumn 1972 the title was changed to the ''[[Bulletin of the John Rylands University Library of Manchester]]'' (further slight changes have occurred since).<ref>Publication was suspended for a few years (1909–13) but it has been published continuously since 1914, either two or three issues a year</ref>
During the First World War 11 members of staff joined the armed forces; of these only Capt. O. J. Sutton, MC, lost his life while serving.<ref>Guppy, Henry (1924) ''The John Rylands University Library, Manchester: 1899-1824''. Manchester: University Press; p. 35</ref> Other noteworthy members of staff were [[James Rendel Harris]], [[Alphonse Mingana]], the Semitic scholar Professor [[Edward Robertson (Semitic scholar)|Edward Robertson]] (d. 1964) who was the third librarian,<ref>''Bulletin of the John Rylands Library'', Vol. 45 (1962/63), pp. 1–2, 273-75; 47 (1964/65), pp. 1–2</ref><ref>''Who was Who; 1961–1970'', p. 966</ref> and [[Moses Tyson]], keeper of western manuscripts, afterwards librarian of Manchester University Library. Stella Butler, a medical historian, was Head of Special Collections from 2000 until 2009, and she moved to the [[University of Leeds]] in 2011 as University Librarian.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://library.leeds.ac.uk/info/200192/library_staff/1038/dr_stella_butler |title=Dr Stella Butler |publisher=University of Leeds |accessdate=9 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leeds.ac.uk/forstaff/news/article/1383/university_librarian_appointment-dr_stella_butler |publisher=University of Leeds |title=University Librarian appointment - Dr Stella Butler |accessdate=9 July 2011}}</ref> Since 2009, Rachel Beckett has been Head of Special Collections and she was appointed as the Associate Director of The John Rylands Library in 2013. Jan Wilkinson has been the Director of The John Rylands Library, as well as University Librarian, since 2008.
==John Rylands Research Institute== Acting Librarian David Miller founded the John Rylands Research Institute in 1987,<ref>{{Cite book|title = A History of the University of Manchester, 1973-90|last = Pullan|first = Brian|publisher = Manchester University Press|year = 2004|isbn = 9780719062421|pages = 261|last2 = Abendstern|first2 = Michele}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mrdwmiller.wordpress.com/|title=The John Rylands Research Institute : The True Tale Told|website=The John Rylands Research Institute : The True Tale Told|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-08}}</ref> to promote, fund and stimulate research on the primary material held at Deansgate.
The John Rylands Research Institute was relaunched in 2014 as a collaboration between the University of Manchester's Faculty of Humanities and the John Rylands Library.<ref>[http://www.manchester.ac.uk/discover/news/university-launches-the-john-rylands-research-institute/] "University launches the John Rylands Research Institute" Retrieved 13 November 2017</ref> The mission of the Institute is to open up the Library's Special Collections to innovative and multidisciplinary research, in partnership with researchers in Manchester and across the globe. In September 2016, Hannah Barker, Professor of British History, took up the role as Director of the John Rylands Research Institute <ref>[http://www.jrri.manchester.ac.uk/about/people/institute-staff/]"The John Rylands Research Institute"</ref> She succeeded Prof. Peter Pormann who had been appointed Director of the John Rylands Research Institute in 2013.
==Governors and Trustees== Mrs Rylands established a board of trustees to hold the library's assets and a council of governors to maintain the building and control expenditure. The council consisted of some representative and some co-optative governors while honorary governors were not members of the council.<ref>John Rylands Library (1969) ''Catalogue of an Exhibition of Manuscripts and Early Printing Originating in Germany ... November 1969''. Manchester: John Rylands Library; list inside cover</ref><ref>Farnie, D. A. (1989). "Enriqueta Augustina Rylands, 1843–1908, Founder of the John Rylands Library". ''Bulletin of the John Rylands University Library of Manchester''; 71 (2): 3–38.</ref> Both these bodies were dissolved at the merger in 1972. Members of the council of governors included Professor [[Arthur Peake]] and Professor [[F. F. Bruce]] both biblical critics and [[Rylands Professor of Biblical Criticism and Exegesis|Rylands Professors of Biblical Criticism and Exegesis]].
==Visitors== Many notable people including heads of state have visited the library. [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] and the Duchess of Cornwall have also visited.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/aboutus/news/royaltyattherylands/ |title=Royalty at the Rylands |accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref>

London: Sotheby's (98 works were offered for sale, of which a few remained unsold; all the books were rare duplicate copies; the funds raised were used to establish the John Rylands Research Institute in 1989) *Taylor, Frank (1989) "The John Rylands Library, 1936–72" in: ''Bulletin of the John Rylands University Library of Manchester'' LXXI,2 (summer 1989); pp. 39–66 *Tyson, Moses (1941) "The First Forty Years of the John Rylands Library" in: ''Bulletin of the John Rylands Library''; vol. revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/Yasmeen_masri|Yasmeen_masri]] ([[User talk:Yasmeen_masri|talk]]): using Wikipedia for [[WP:NOTADVERTISING|advertising/promotion]] ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
[[File:Quseir Amra Fresque personnage.jpg|thumb|Fresco at [[Qasr Amra|Qusayr Amra]] Hamman (bath-house), an example of [[Umayyad Caliphate|Umayyad]] art from Jordan, 8th century]] '''Jordanian art''' has a very ancient history. Some of the earliest figurines, found at Aïn Ghazal, near Amman, have been dated to the Neolithic period. A distinct Jordanian aesthetic in art and architecture emerged as part of a broader [[Islamic art]] tradition which flourished from the 7th-century. Traditional art and craft is vested in material culture including mosaics, ceramics, weaving, silver work, music, glass-blowing and calligraphy. The rise of colonialism in North Africa and the Middle East, led to a dilution of traditional aesthetics. In the early 20th-century, following the creation of the independent nation of Jordan, a contemporary Jordanian art movement emerged and began to search for a distinctly Jordanian art aesthetic that combined both tradition and contemporary art forms.
==Traditional art== {{main article|Islamic art}} Jordan, as an independent nation was founded in 1924. Prior to that, the area that is now Jordan had been subject to a number of different rules. It was part of the [[Nabatean Kingdom]], under Hellenistic rule following Alexander the Great's conquest of the area; under Roman rule in the 1st century BCE,<ref>Beienkowski, P., ''The Art of Jordan,'' Stroud, Allan Sutton, 1991, pp. 16-17</ref> and was once part of the [[Umayyad]] Kingdom in the 7th century (CE) and part of the [[Ottoman Empire]] from the 15th-century until the end of World War I<ref>Bloom, J.M. and Blair, S. S., ''The Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture,'' pp 362-363; Taylor, J. ''Petra and the Lost Kingdom of the Nabataeans,'' I.B. Tauris, 2001, p. 11 and p. 47 </ref> when it became a British protectorate until the time of independence.<ref>Zuhur, S. (ed.), ''Colors of Enchantment: Theater, Dance, Music, and the Visual Arts of the Middle East, ''American University in Cairo Press, 2001, p. 369</ref> Its art is part a broader Islamic artistic tradition, with evidence of classical influences.<ref>''Mideast File,'' Vol. 4, Learned Information, 1985, p. 265</ref>
Traditional art was often based on material culture including hand-crafts such as rug-making, basket weaving, silver smithing, mosaics, ceramics, and glass-blowing. The Bedouins were largely self-sufficient in the production of goods, and made their own rugs, wove baskets and prepared ceramics. Such works exhibited wide variation in styles, as tribes often used their own tribal motifs.<ref>Bienkowski, P. and van der Steen, E., "Tribes, Trade, and Towns: A New Framework for the Late Iron Age in Southern Jordan and the Negev," ''Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research,'' No. 323 (Aug., 2001), pp. 21-47</ref>
The Jordanian art historian, [[Wijdan Ali]] has argued that the traditional Islamic aesthetic evident in craft-based work was displaced by the arrival of colonialism in North Africa and the Middle East.<ref>Ali, W., ''Contemporary Art from the Islamic World,'' London, Scorpion Publishing, 1989</ref> However, in the decolonised period of the 20th-century, a contemporary art form combining tradition and modern influences can be observed.<ref>Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, p. 1294; Lindgren, A. and Ross, S., ''The Modernist World,'' Routledge, 2015, p. 495; Mavrakis, N., "The Hurufiyah Art Movement in Middle Eastern Art," ''McGill Journal of Middle Eastern Studies Blog,'' Online: https://mjmes.wordpress.com/2013/03/08/article-5/; Tuohy, A. and Masters, C., ''A-Z Great Modern Artists,'' Hachette UK, 2015, p. 56; Ramadan, K.D., ''Peripheral Insider: Perspectives on Contemporary Internationalism in Visual Culture,'' Museum Tusculanum Press, 2007, p. 49; Asfour. M., "A Window on Contemporary Arab Art," NABAD Art Gallery, Online: http://www.nabadartgallery.com/</ref>
===Pre-Islamic art===
As early as the Neolithic period in Jordan, figurines and sculptures were being made. In some of the earliest examples, human skulls were built up with plaster, and inlays were used for the eye sockets.<ref>Adams, L.S., ''The Methodologies of Art: An Introduction,'' Routledge, 2018, [E-book edition], n.p.</ref> Two caches of figurines discovered at Aïn Ghazal, near Amman, include animal models and some three dozen monumental figurines (pictured below), which scholars believe were important to the ritual and social structure of the peoples living there,<ref>Mithen, S., ''After the Ice: A Global Human History, 20,000 - 5000 BC,'' UK, Hachette UK, 2011, [E-book edition], n.p.</ref> and may have formed part of a burial ritual.<ref>Kleiner, F.S., ''Gardner's Art through the Ages: A Concise Western History,'' Cengage Learning, 2016, p. 21</ref> The [['Ain Ghazal Statues|'Ain Ghazal statues]] are very large, with some around three feet in height. Aïn Ghazal was occupied between 7,000 BCE and 5,000 BCE and the statues have been dated to around 6,500 BCE.<ref>Kleiner, F.S., ''Gardner's Art through the Ages: A Concise Western History,'' Cengage Learning, 2016, pp. 20-21</ref> Showing extensive use of plaster,<ref>Bourke, S., ''The Middle East: The Cradle of Civilization Revealed,'' Thames & Hudson, 2008, p. 43</ref> the Aïn Ghazal statues represent a clear departure from the tiny, faceless figures of the Paleolithic period and mark the dawn of a distinct Neolithic art.<ref>Kleiner, F.S., ''Gardner's Art through the Ages: A Concise Western History,'' Cengage Learning, 2016, pp. 20-21</ref>
The [[Nabateans]] incorporated numerous sculpted panels, figurines and decorative friezes into their buildings at [[Petra]] and made pottery. Examples include the architectural detail used on the temple of Qsr al-Bint at Petra<ref>Basile, J.J., "Recently Discovered Relief Sculptures from the Great Temple at Amman," ''Annual of the Department of Antiquities of Jordan, vol. 46, The Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, Amman, 2002</ref> and the prevalent stele representing the gods, as carved reliefs and either cut directly into the rock-face or carved as stand-alone units and placed inside carved niches.<ref>Patrich, J., ''The Formation of Nabataean Art: Prohibition of a Graven Image Among the Nabateans,'' Brill Archive, 1990, pp. 59-76</ref>
The Romans conquered Palestine and Syria in 64-63 BCE, and annexed Nabatea in 106 CE by which time the whole of Jordan fell under Roman rule. The Roman occupation corresponded with a flowering of the visual arts - painting, architecture. By the time of the Emperor Justinian (527-565 CE), churches dotted Jordan's landscape and these featured intricate mosaic floors, frescoes and porticos.<ref>"The Art of Ancient Jordan," in ''Minerva,'' Aurora Publications, 1991, pp. 20-24</ref>
<gallery> File:Ain Ghazal Statues Jordan Archaeological Museum Amman Jordan0822.jpg|Ain Ghazal Statues, Neolithic period, 6700-6500 BCE, now in the Jordan Archaeological Museum, Amman File:Statue Aïn Ghazal Louvre AO 14012018 2.jpg|Aïn Ghazal Statue, now in the Louvre File:PetraQasr-el-Bint-TrabeazioneFiancoSx.jpg|Frieze at the Qasr-el-Bint Temple, Petra File:PetraQasr-el-BintDecorazioneStuccoRetro.jpg|Stucco at Qasr-el-Bint, Petra File:Nabataean Petroglyph ACOR Jordan0872.jpg|Nabataean Petroglyph, 2nd or 3rd century File:Nabataean betyl 1.JPG|Nabataean betyl (sacred stone or stone slab)
</gallery>
===Islamic art === {{main|Islamic art}} The [[Umayyad]] period marks the starting point of Islamic art and architecture.<ref>Genequand, D., "Umayyad Castles: The Shift From Late Antique Military Architecture to Early Islamic Palatial Building," in: Kennedy, H (ed.), ''Muslim Military Architecture in Greater Syria: from the Coming of Islam to the Ottoman Period,'' [History of Warfare Series], vol. 35, no. 2, Boston Brill, Leiden, 2006, pp. 3-25; Yalman, S., "The Art of the Umayyad Period (661–750)," ''The Met Museum,'' [https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/umay/hd_umay.htm Online:]</ref> The wealth and patronage of the [[Umayyad]] period stimulated the construction of religious, administrative and royal residences as well as prompting a distinctive style of ''bayt'' (domestic home). Jordan has some of the finest examples of early Islamic architecture including: [[caravanserai]]s, [[desert castles]] (in Arabic known as ''qusayr''), bath-houses, hunting lodges and palaces located in the fringe of the eastern desert.<ref>Genequand, D., "Umayyad Castles; The Shift From Late Antique Military Architecture to Early Islamic Palatial Building," in: Kennedy, H (ed.), ''Muslim Military Architecture in Greater Syria: from the Coming of Islam to the Ottoman Period,'' [History of Warfare Series], vol. 35, no. 2, Boston Brill, Leiden, 2006, pp. 3-25</ref>
Examples of great mosques constructed during the rule of the Umayyad caliph [[Al-Walid I]] (705-714) include: the [[Umayyad Mosque|Great Mosque of Damascus]] (706 CE), the [[Al-Aqsa Mosque]] of Jerusalem (715 CE), and the Mosque of the Prophet in Medina (709-715). Since the mid 19th-century, a number of the Umayyad sites have been excavated, revealing stunning frescoes, wall and ceiling paintings and statuary.<ref>Fowden, G., ''Qusayr 'Amra: Art and the Umayyad Elite in Late Antique Syria,'' University of California Press, 2004, p. 49</ref> One of these paintings, the ''[[Painting of the Six Kings]]'' has been the subject of considerable scholarship with respect to its interpretation.<ref>Grabar, O., "The Painting of the Six Kings at Quṣayr 'Amrah," ''Ars Orientalis,'' Vol. 1, 1954, pp. 185-187</ref>
Notable frescoes and relief carvings can be found the [[desert castles]] of Quasyr Al Hallabat; [[Qasr Al-Kharanah|Quasyr al-Kharanah]], [[Qasr Azraq|Quasyr el-Azraq]], [[Qasr Mshatta]] and the [[Qasr Amra|Quasyr 'Amra]] which features frescoes of hunting scenes, musicians, acrobats, entertainers, nude women, wrestlers and scenes of the Royal court.<ref>Fowden, G., ''Qusayr 'Amra: Art and the Umayyad Elite in Late Antique Syria,'' University of California Press, 2004, especially see pp 55-68 for descriptions of the frescoes at Qusayr 'Amra</ref> Lesser desert castles include [[Qasr Tuba|Quasyr al-Tuba]]; [[Qasr al-Hayr al-Gharbi|Quasyr al-Hayr al-Gharbi]]; [[Qasr Burqu'|Quasyr Burqu']], Qasr el `Uweinid and Qasr el Feifeh. <ref>Kennedy, D. and Riley, D., ''Rome's Desert Frontiers,'' Routledge, 2012, pp. 8-9</ref>
Poetry and calligraphy were elevated to high art. Under the [[Umayyad]], writing assumed a special place, often based on scripture and the life of the prophet, Mahommed, but often seen as the carrier of independent meaning and a subject worthy of ornamentation.<ref>Ettinghausen, R., Grabar, O. and Jenkins, K. (eds.), ''Islamic Art and Architecture, 650-1250 ''Yale University Press, 2001, p. 79</ref> Master calligraphers were venerated. The art of calligraphy was passed from master to student in a formal, rigorous system of training that took place over many years, required for students to learn the strict rules and protocols that governed the art form. Both religious and secular writing flourished under the Umayyad dynasty.
Poets, (known as ''sha'ir'' meaning wizard) were thought to be inspired by a spirit (''jinn''), and were expected to defend the honour of their tribe, and to perpetuate its deeds and accomplishments.<ref>''Islamic Art, Literature, and Culture,'' Britannica Educational Publishing, 2009, pp. 58-60</ref> The [[Mu'allaqat]], a collection of seven poems by different poets, although pre-Islamic in origin, is thought to be the precursor to Arabic poetry.
<gallery> File:Qasr Amra 4.jpg|Wall fresco at Quasyr 'Amra, 8th-century File:Qasr Amra moz 18.jpg|Frescoes at Quasyr 'Amra, 8th century File:Fresco Qasr Amra Jordan1072.jpg|Detail of Fresco Quasyr 'Amra, 8th century File:Qasr Al Hallabat, mosaic floor.jpg|Mosaic floor at Quasyr Al Hallabat File:20141107-jordanie-hammam as sarah-008.jpg|Ceiling of Hammam al-Sarah, at Quasyr Al Hallabat File:Humeima ivory.jpg|Ivory, Abbasid Homestead in Humeima, Jordan. The style indicates an origin in northeastern Iran File:Blooming at Qasar Kharana.JPG|Decorative feature from [[Qasr Al-Kharanah|Quasyr al-Kharanah]] File:Sixkings.jpg|Painting of the Six Kings, (damaged) Quasyr 'Amra </gallery>
==Early modern art== The origins of modern art in Jordan have their roots in the 1920s and 1930s when a small number of artists settled in Amman. [[Omar Onsi]] (1901-1969) was a Lebanese artist who settled in Amman in around 1922,<ref>Bloom, J.M. and Blair, S. S., ''The Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture,'' pp. 362-363; Zuhur, S. (ed.), ''Colors of Enchantment: Theater, Dance, Music, and the Visual Arts of the Middle East,''American University in Cairo Press, 2001, p. 375</ref> and gave painting lessons to the children of Abdullah I.<ref name="Naef1996">{{cite book|last=Naef|first=Silvia |title=À la recherche d'une modernité arabe: l'évolution des arts plastiques en Égypte, au Liban et en Irak|page=160|year=1996|publisher=Slatkine|isbn=978-2-05-101376-5|language=French}}</ref> In 1930, the Turkish artist, Ziauddin Suleiman (1880-1945) also settled in Amman and held the first solo exhibition at the Philadelphia Hotel.<ref>Bloom, J.M. and Blair, S. S., ''The Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture,'' pp. 362-363</ref> In 1948, [[George Aleef]] arrived in Jordan with a group of Palestinian refugees and set up an art studio where he taught local students.<ref> Zuhur, S., ''Colors of Enchantment: Theater, Dance, Music, and the Visual Arts of the Middle East,'' American University in Cairo Press, 2001, p. 375</ref> These three artists introduced local students to easel painting and contributed to a broader appreciation of art. <ref>Bloom, J.M. and Blair, S. S., ''The Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art and Architecture,'' p. 362 </ref>
As late as the 1940s, Jordan had no art galleries and art exhibitions were virtually unknown.<ref>Mostyn, T., ''Jordan: A Meed Practical Guide,'' Middle East Economic Digest Limited, Jordan, 1983, p. 72; the author claims that the first art exhibition was held in 1938 but adds no detail. However, different sources claim that the first art exhibition was held in 1951, See: ''Jordan,'' Jordan Information Bureau, 1981, p. 53 and Jonathan Bloom and Sheila S. Blair (eds), ''Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art & Architecture,'' Vol. 1, Oxford University Press, 2009, p. 362</ref> The few art exhibitions that were mounted, were held in public spaces such as schools and the halls of parliament.
==Jordanian modern art movement== In the late 1950s, a group of young artists who had trained in Europe, returned to Jordan to lay the foundations of the ''Jordanian modern art movement.''<ref>Zuhur. S., ''Colors of Enchantment: Theater, Dance, Music, and the Visual Arts of the Middle East,'' American University in Cairo Press, 2001, p. 377</ref> A number of these students, including [[Muhanna Al-Dura]], Rafiq Lahham, and Suha Katibah Noursi, received their earliest art education in Jordan from the Russian émigré, [[George Aleef]], who was the first Western painter to establish a studio in Amman and teach local students. According to Muhanna Dura's memoirs, Aleef taught his students the basics of watercolor, drawing and painting, and the European understanding of perspective.<ref>Rogers, S., "Mohanna Durra," in ''Mathaf Encyclopedia of Modern Art and the Arab World, Online: http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org.qa/en/bios/Pages/Mohanna-Durra.aspx; Mejcher-Atassi, S. and Schwartz, J.P., ''Archives, Museums and Collecting Practices in the Modern Arab World,'' Routledge, 2016, p. 175; Mejcher-Atassi, S. and Schwartz, J.P., ''Archives, Museums and Collecting Practices in the Modern Arab World,'' Routledge, 2016, p. 175</ref> Dura along with these young artists helped to spark a local, Jordanian art movement. <ref>Mejcher-Atassi, S. and Schwartz, J.P., ''Archives, Museums and Collecting Practices in the Modern Arab World,'' Routledge, 2016, p.175</ref>
Muhanna Dura ultimately taught painting and art history at the Teachers' Training College in Ammman and in 1964, established the Fine Arts Section at the Department of Culture and Art, Amman, and also established the Jordan Institute of Fine Arts in 1970. Thus, he inspired a generation of young artists. Among his notable students were the Princess [[Wijdan Ali]] who is best known for her attempts to revive the traditions of Islamic art.<ref>Hashem Talham, G., ''Historical Dictionary of Women in the Middle East and North Africa,'' Rowman & Littlefield, 2013, p. 24</ref> and Nawal Abdallah, who is one of the leading lights of Jordan's contemporary arts scene and whose art often includes calligraphy.<ref>Teller, M., "A Hit List of Jordanian Artists" in ''Jordan,'' Rough Guides, 2002, p. 425</ref>
A second group of artists, who trained in Europe and America in the 1960s, returned to Jordan and began to search for a distinctive Jordanian artistic expression and to assert their Arab identity. Notable artists in the Jordanian art movement include: Khalid Khreis (b. 1955); Nabil Shehadeh (b. 1949); Yasser Duwaik (b. 1940); [[Mahmoud Taha]] (b. 1942) and Aziz Amoura (b. 1944).<ref>Zuhur. S., ''Colors of Enchantment: Theater, Dance, Music, and the Visual Arts of the Middle East,'' American University in Cairo Press, 2001, pp. 377-78</ref>
==Hurufiyah art movement== [[File:Roof of Frere Hall.JPG|thumb|Roof of [[Frere Hall]], Karachi, Pakistan, c. 1986. Pakmural by artist, [[Sadequain|Sadequain Naqqash]], integrates calligraphy into a contemporary artwork]]
{{main|Hurufiyya movement}} The Hurufiyah Art Movement (also known as the ''Al-hurufiyyah movement'' or the ''North African Letterist movement'') refers to the use of calligraphy as a graphic form within an artwork.<ref>Mavrakis, N., "The Hurufiyah Art Movement in Middle Eastern Art," ''McGill Journal of Middle Eastern Studies Blog,'' Online: https://mjmes.wordpress.com/2013/03/08/article-5/;Tuohy, A. and Masters, C., ''A-Z Great Modern Artists,'' Hachette UK, 2015, p. 56</ref> From around 1955, artists working in North Africa and parts of Asia transformed Arabic calligraphy into a modern art movement.<ref>Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, p. 1294</ref> The use of calligraphy in modern art arose independently in various Islamic states; few of these artists had knowledge of each other, allowing for different manifestations of hurufiyyah to emerge in different regions. <ref>Dadi. I., "Ibrahim El Salahi and Calligraphic Modernism in a Comparative Perspective," ''South Atlantic Quarterly,'' 109 (3), 2010 pp 555-576, DOI:https://doi.org/10.121500382876-2010-006; Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, p. 1294 </ref> In Sudan, for instance, artworks include both Islamic calligraphy and West African motifs.<ref>Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, p. 1298-1299</ref> [[File:Roof of Frere Hall (3).JPG|thumb|Detail of Roof of Frere Hall]] Hurufiyah artists rejected Western art concepts, and instead searched for a new artistic identity drawn from within their own culture and heritage. These artists successfully integrate Islamic visual traditions, especially calligraphy, into contemporary, indigenous compositions.<ref>Lindgren, A. and Ross, S., ''The Modernist World,'' Routledge, 2015, p. 495; Mavrakis, N., "The Hurufiyah Art Movement in Middle Eastern Art," ''McGill Journal of Middle Eastern Studies Blog,'' Online: https://mjmes.wordpress.com/2013/03/08/article-5/; Tuohy, A. and Masters, C., ''A-Z Great Modern Artists,'' Hachette UK, 2015, p. 56</ref> Although hurufiyah artists were concerned with their individual dialogue with nationalism and attempted to engage with the modern art movement, they also worked towards an aesthetic that transcended national boundaries and represented a broader affiliation with an Islamic identity. <ref>Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, p. 1294</ref>
Jordan's most notable exponents of hurufiyyah art are the ceramicist, [[Mahmoud Taha]] and the artist and art historian, [[Wijdan Ali|Princess Wijdan Ali]] who through her writing has been able to bring the art movement to the attention of a broader audience.<ref>Ramadan, K.D., ''Peripheral Insider: Perspectives on Contemporary Internationalism in Visual Culture,'' Museum Tusculanum Press, 2007, p. 49; Mavrakis, N., "The Hurufiyah Art Movement in Middle Eastern Art," ''McGill Journal of Middle Eastern Studies Blog,'' Online: https://mjmes.wordpress.com/2013/03/08/article-5/</ref>
==Art galleries and museums==
[[File:Ayn Ghazal Bust.jpg|thumb|The Ayn Ghazal Bust, on display at the Jordanian Museum, is estimated to be 9,500 years old and is the oldest known human figure]]
* [[Jordan National Gallery of Fine Arts]] * Jabal Luwiebdeh Art Museum * Khalid Shoman Foundation, Darat al Funun * Dar Al-Anda, Amman - a museum and research centre<ref>Reynolds, D.F. (ed.), ''The Cambridge Companion to Modern Arab Culture,'' Cambridge University Press, 2015, p. 204</ref> * Foresight32 Art Gallery, Amman * Nabad, Amman * Wadi Finan, Amman * Orfali Gallery, Um Uthaina * Orient Gallery, Abdoun, West Amman * Jacaranda, Amman * Cairo Amman Bank Gallery, Wadi Saqra, Amman
==See also== * [[Calligraphy]] * [[Desert castles]] * [[Islamic art]] * [[Islamic architecture]] * [[Islamic calligraphy]] * [[Jordan National Gallery of Fine Arts]] * [[List of Orientalist artists]] * [[List of Jordanians]] * [[Osman Waqialla]] * [[Umayyad architecture]]
===Notable historic architectural sites ===
* [[Amman Citadel|Jabal al-Qal'a]] - group of upper-class houses * [[Al Qastal, Jordan]] - Ummayad palace * [[Hammam al-Sarah]] - Ummayad bath-house * [[Qasr Amra]] - Ummayad palace * [[Qasr Al-Hallabat]] - desert castle/ hunting lodge * [[Qasr Al-Kharanah]] - desert castle * [[Qasr Al-Mshatta]] -desert castle * [[Qasr Burqu']] -desert castle * [[Qasr Tuba]] - desert castle
==References==
{{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.aneesmaani.com Sculptures by Anees Maani] * [http://www.alqam.com Paintings by Hani Alqam] * [http://jumannimri.com Prints by Juman Nimri] * [http://www.jordanembassyus.org/page/culture-and-religion The Embassy of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan: Culture and Religion]
==Further reading== * Piotr Bienkowski, ''Treasures from an Ancient Land: The Art of Jordan,'' A. Sutton Publishing, 1994, 1996 * Peter Vine, ''Jewels of the Kingdom: The Heritage of Jordan,'' Immel, 1987

[[File:Nepalese lakhe dancer.jpg|thumb|200px|Majipa Lakhe of Kathmandu.]] [[File:Dhading lakhe.jpg|thumb|200px|A Lakhe dancer from Dhading in Kathmandu.]] [[File:Bhojpur lakhe.jpg|thumb|200px|Bhojpur Lakhe in Kathmandu.]] '''Lākhey''' ([[Nepal Bhasa]]: लाखे, lā-khé) (alternative spellings '''Lākhe''', '''Lākhay''', लाखय्) is a demon in Nepalese folklore. He is depicted with a ferocious face, protruding fangs and mane of red or black hair. Lakhes figure prominently in traditional [[Newar]] culture of [[Nepal Mandala]]. The Lakhe tradition is found in the [[Kathmandu Valley]] and other Newar settlements throughout [[Nepal]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Gurung| first = Anuj | authorlink = | coauthors = | url = http://www.culturalsurvival.org/publications/cultural-survival-quarterly/nepal/demon-among-deities| title = A Demon Among Deities| work = Cultural Survival| publisher = | date=Spring 2009| accessdate = 23 July 2012}}</ref>
Lakhes are said to be demons who used to live in the forests and later became protectors to the townspeople.<ref>Trussler, Simon and Barker, Clive (1 September 2003). ''New Theatre Quarterly 74, Volume 19.'' Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|0521535891}}, 9780521535892. Page 127.</ref> A female Lakhe is known as Lasin (लसिं).
The other common legendary being in Nepalese folklore is the [[Khyah (legendary creature)|Khyāh]], who is depicted as a fat, hairy ape-like creature.
==Dancing Lakhes==
Lakhey Dance is one of the most popular dances of Nepal. Performers wearing a Lakhe costume and mask perform dances on the streets and city squares during festivals. The mask is made of [[papier-mâché]] and [[yak]] tails are used for the hair. The Lakhe dance is characterised by wild movements and thumping music.<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | url = http://www.sikkim-culture.gov.in/Dances/Trance%20Dances.aspx| title = Lakhey Mask Dance| work = | publisher = Cultural Affairs and Heritage Department, Government of Sikkim| date=| accessdate = 24 July 2012}}</ref>
The most famous Lakhe is [[Majipa Lakhey]] of [[Kathmandu]] who appears during the [[Yenya]] (Indra Jatra) festival in September.<ref>{{cite web | last = Toffin| first = Gérard | authorlink = | coauthors = | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/64459961/Indra-Jatra-of-Kathmandu-Gerard-Toffin| title = The Indra Jātrā of Kathmandu as a Royal Festival Past and Present| work = Contributions to Nepalese Studies| publisher = Center for Nepal and Asian Studies, Tribhuvan University| date=January 1992| accessdate = 24 July 2012}} Page 73.</ref><ref>Koizumi, Fumio (1983). ''Dance and music in South Asian drama: Chhau, Mahākālī pyākhan and Yakshagāna.'' Academia Music. Page 5.</ref> He is worshipped as a deity. City dwellers offer food and ritual items to him as he moves through the city accompanied by his musical band giving dance performances.
The Lakhe stops at major crossroads and market squares to give a performance. During the dance, a small boy is known as Jhyalincha (झ्यालिंचा) taunts the Lakhe making him chase him in anger. Jhyalincha always manages to slip into the crowd and escape.<ref>{{cite book |last=Bajracharya |first=Chunda |editor-first=Subash Ram |editor-last=Prajapati |title=The Masked Dances of Nepal Mandal|publisher=Thimi: Madhyapur Art Council|date=2006|chapter=Majipa Lakhe|isbn=99946-707-0-0}} Page 19.</ref>
Gunla Lakhe comes out during [[Gunla]], the 10th month in the [[Nepal Sambat]] calendar which corresponds to August.
==Other Lakhes==
There are other Lakhes with particular characteristics. These mythical beings are said to reside in various parts of the city.
* Michyāh Lākhe (मिच्या: लाखे) (meaning "fire burning demon" in [[Nepal Bhasa]]) is a spirit who is said to cause a fire by [[spontaneous combustion]] wherever it resides. People possessed by Michyāh Lakhe are also believed to cause a fire. * Minpu Lākhe (मिंपू लाखे) also causes a fire.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Newar}}
